div.p: The attributes and descriptions remain in place as Harnworld requires them (at least for some characters). In other words, without them, a character designed toward a specific career would be incomplete in the setting. They are also not transformed in any way. Generation of values can be used as suggested. Relationship and Loyalty for contacts are descriptive only.
Sunsigns are treated as direct modifiers, where they have a numeric value.
The attributes described are translated (linearly) into the range -15 to 15. Moraliy is dropped. Generation of values can be used as suggested.
The occupations of the table on this page serve as skills and the listed "old" skills serve only as descriptive values.

Automatic skills are determined accoridng to the appropriate skill section (q.v.) and Occupation skills work as transformed for the previous page. They open as 20 for the chosen occupation. Family skills for parents in the same occupation add 2 points, while for a different occupation they add 5. (This is effectively Row-5-addition of a 0 skill level.) Optional skills are as they exist, but new skills may be "invented"; the scope is at GM discretion. Any reasoonable skill can be improved by 5 for each option point (OP) through Row-5-addition; this includes OPs gained for Veterans. Militia skills are explained elsewhere as are psionics.
Rules on these page are completely dropped currently. Generation of values can be used as suggested.

Each clerical occupation is treated as a separate occupation, with the "old" skills being used in a descriptive sense. The same is true for the Shek-Pvar. Chantry Applications are dropped. Treat Sunsigns as direct modifiers from the Convocational Sunsign Modifiers for magic invocations. Magic does not work along spell lines (q.v.). Each military occupation is treated as a separate occupation as well.

Table results from these page are used purely in their descriptive sense. Whether they retroractively have any effect on other attributes is a choice that can be made during character creation and according to the severity or interpretation of the result that you want to portait. Piety is turned into a skill (q.v.) for each deity. For a single deity the value can be chosen or generated as suggested. All others are 0 initially.

ul.li: Level 0: NN knows that the reigion exist but cannot separate it from other convocations.
Level 5: Lip service payed to the religion and ability to separate it from other major faiths.
Level 10: The main tenants of the religion are known and followed on individual level. Sects or heresies are not considered.
Level 15: The religion is quoted often and other faiths routinely treated underhanded. Proselytizing is rarely attempted.
Level 20: At this level the adherent is actively seeking to further the tenants of the religion outside of his immediate domain. Distinction between inner-religion minutiae are important.
Level 25: Heresy is abhorred more than other religions. Support for the religion takes precendents over other interests almost always.
Level 30: The adherent is a prophet for the religion and accepts otherwise serious consequences for following details of his faith. May invent rituals and the like.

div.p: These pages are ignored.

Sunsigns affect certain applications of skills. Since the "old" skills still remain in their descriptive sense, a player should announce, when he feels like his sunsign would apply to a situation. Sunsigns are direct modifiers.

Available skills are according to the occupations listed, determined by Harnworld professions. More skills may be created according to players' or GM's wishes. Certain applications of skills are provided below with result tables to allow comparisons.

All penalties described are available and will be used where they makes sense individually. They are applied to a skill level or attribute level as direct modifier an they are neither restricted to certain tests nor do they automatically apply to others. The encumbrance penalty is calculated from the derived attribute of the same name, see the tables.
Fatigue is recovered at a rate of 1 level per minute.

Learning is modelled by an active roll with level 0 against a passive level of the current skill. Note that rolling 10 non-stop events can be shortened into rolling a 1 with a d10. Learning is applicable to attributes but the active roll is level -15.

Such rolls may be made once a month in which the skill was used reasonably often. Usually only three such rolls apply. A teacher can also be combined with his own skill reduced by 10 through Row-5-addition. This assumes that the teacher is available almost always during that time.

Example: Suppose your skill is at 5 and your teacher has a skill of 12. According to the rules, we should first take the highest of the two parameters to be combined into a single skill roll, that is 0 and 2 (12 - 10). Remember your active level is 0 in this situation. Taking the difference of, we have a column index of 2 into the combination table and we read in the fifth row a 5, which will be added to 2 (the higher of the two numbers) to yield a 7. That is the active skill level to roll against your current skill level (5) to improve. We are pitting a 7 against a 5 with roughly a 70% chance of success and upon success the skill level is increased to 6.
These pages are considered descriptive only. Mental Conflict resolution follows the Combat rules, with defenses set to zero, modified by magic items, rituals, etc..
If a more pragmatic approach is desired, use the following "reversed" table for finding the addition.

Situations which require rolls are announced by the GM with a general description of what needs to be resolved. Players will then argue, which skills could be applicable and the GM will give a corresponding percentage of how much they apply.
For example, an assessment of the correct political relation between two rival noble families may be Herald/75% and Knight/50%, and Mercantyler/25%.

Now roll for all applicable skills you have a value in. (Remember that a base 0 always applies.) In the example above, the mercantyler has a 1 in 4 chance of using his mercantyler skill, say 12, and a 3 in 4 chance of using his knight skill 0. All skills which were succeessfully rolled for are added up through Row-3-addition from the main rules . The end result is the skill to roll against.
Healing time for 1 injury point. Note the switch between days and watches.

Humans can accelerate and decelerate as 3 m/s each second. Turning options are in parts of a full circle (centered around the direction of travel). E.g. at 3 m/s this means 60° off the direction of travel on either side per second. For the sake of playability variance in this should be suppressed, although a 20% spread (for a 10 level difference) with Agility modification could be appropriate.
Horses accelerate and decelerate at 6 m/s each second but have the same turning options.

Fatigue is acrued at the 10 points per minute (or 1 per second) for the generated maximum sprint speed. Fractions (which cannot exceed 1) of that speed generate the corresponding fractional fatigue rate. E.g. running at half the maximum speed gives 5 points per minute (or 1 per 12 seconds). Only simple fractions are allowed.

The listed weight can be lifted without dedicated tools. At that point any activity is at -10. This scales linearly down or up. That means that any fraction of the weight carried also incurs the same fraction of -10 as penalty. Any multiple carried also gives the corresponding multiple as penalty. Note that with certain penalties usually trivial activities (i.e. no roll required) become difficult, for instance not stumbling.
Still without tools, activity with both hands is impossible. Freeing one hand incurs twice the penalty and assumes that the weight is liftable that way.

Fatigue is acrued at the 10 points per minute (or 1 per second) for the generated maximum lift. Fractions (which cannot exceed 1) of that lift generate the corresponding fractional fatigue rate. E.g. lifting half the maximum weight gives 5 points per minute (or 1 per 12 seconds). Only simple fractions are allowed.
The description is based on the expected outcome, i.e. simply read the result rolled as index row in the table.
Typical modifications are made for contrast (+), movement (+), distraction (-), border of visual field (-)
These pages are ignored. Some paragraphs may be taken for their descriptive value only. Combat fatigue is 1 point per minute.

Endurance equals Stamina. Move is a velocity as given above. Dodge is added to Defense through Row-5-Addition. On the Weapon Data the Skill and OML are ignored. A/D and HM are divided by 5. Custom weapon are descriptive only. Every weapon additionally has a reach/length.

Charging is an attack that must end when the corresponding movement stops. Read the move/speed table in reverse to get the damage bonus. Note that the time of attack is fixed and assumed as 10s; the skill is calculated in reverse as well, i.e. -20.

Armour is used as is, except the Protection and Encumbrance part, wich is only descriptive. The bonus to an attack is a bonus of attacker's choice between all the relevant B/E/P values of his weapon. After the goal is reached, the corresponding defender B/E/P is deducted from the wound level.
Defense is calculated as Row-5-addition of Dodge and Block. Both are voluntary and may be subject to individual reductions. Missiles are dodged at half value.

Missile range is interpreted as follows: at range 0, no penalties applies, at half short range -10 applies. At medium, short, extreme range listed the penalties -20, -40, -80 apply. Between those fixed values, apply linear interpolation.
These pages are taken as is.

Mounted combat considers rider and mount to be one unit that have added their skills in the usual manner. The steed provides unarmed combat prowress. Unhorsing is dealt with as collateral damage to the rider/horse combination, which has a defense rating of the rider's skill.

The following table is rolled for each combatant, adding any bonuses and subtracting any penalties. The time is the number of seconds, which it takes to achieve the set wound level zero. The wound level can be set higher, but then this number is subtracted. Estimated time and level can be played out against each other. The intended wound level must be declared before the roll and in multiples of 5. Once a (rolled) progression has reached its goal, a new skill roll is necessary.

Any effects from wounds or other external influences in combat are applied immediately to pending progressions. At the actors choice it can offset the goal or the time. To prevent players from immediately aborting "bad" rolls, mandatory secret rolls by the GM can be used.

If so desired, the intended wound level can be randomized in the usual way. This can not be modified except through control. Alternatively, if time is fixed, a best effort attack can be made. For instance, if an opponent was downed and will get up within a few seconds and the bonus shall be used for better or worse. In that case always spread the actual wound level around the least favorable time for the attacker.

Hit location is determined when the goal is reached. Before the goal is reached, a penalty of -1 can be taken to reduce the possible hit locations by one Main area. This penalty can be taken multiple times but the remaining main hit locations must be (bodily) connected. If all but one main location has been eliminated, individual percentage points may be reduced for a Detail area. This penalty can again be taken multiple times but the remaining detail hit locations must be (bodily) connected.

Individual wounds are tracked numerically and with their location. Effects on the use of the corresponding part are described below. Minor effects are at 10 less than the original wound level and serious effects at 5 less.

ul.li: 6-10: Serious, serious use effect on neighbouring detailed body parts.
11-15: Grievous, the detailed body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring detailed body parts, and minor on main parts.
16-20: Incapacitating, the main body part cannot be used, minor use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For head this means unconsciousness and for thorax imminent death.)

21+:Destroyed, the main body part lost its integrity, serious use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For limbs this means at least severed. Thorax is split open or spinal cord severed. For all but the extremities this means instant death. For all other body parts, death is probably imminent due to the side effects.)

div.p: A wound level 5 points above Dexterity on an arm causes any object held to be dropped (Fumble). A wound level 5 points above Agility on a leg causes the victim to fall down (Stumble). Technically, such rolls can be made once a wound of any level is inflicted, but for playability, sticking with the average is recommended.

Multiple attackers can combine their efforts through Row-5-addition into one. This is generally a complex topic, because modifiers need to be accomodated as they enter the game, so this is best reserved for NPCs that perform as single units. Multiple defendants are similarly added; effectively a Row-5-multipication, since the same skill applies repeatedly.

Hitting the wrong target can happen in melee and in missile combat. Usually this is ignored, but if this ignorance is taken into account when deciding on action options, such accidents shall be played out. Anybody within the (abstract) range of the weapon is subject to a level -5 attack. This can be added to the benefit of other attackers as per multiple attacks above or resolved individually with the goal of 0 damage. Since missile attacks are resolved with indiviual shots, such an attack is applied only if the intended attack had no impact. (Note the different effect from collateral damage that is actually desired.)

Weapon and armour damage is treated as collateral damage in the above sense and usually ignored. If required, WQ and the highest armour protective value is used as defense against such damage. Human body quality is 0, but recall the armour layering effect; outer layers break first.

Certain weapons can be used to entangle, including human arms and legs. Real damage from such attacks is 10 points less than what the actual result says. The effects of the actual result cause the weapon itself to be disabled. Disentaglement takes a level 0 attack against the actual result by the victim. Others, including the attacker, may help or take advantage of the situation.

Unarmed combat is usually not used to inflict much damage, but rather directed at making the opponent stumble, fumble, or unable to use a limb. A prone opponent is then easier to control. Unfortunately, this makes heavy use of the collateral damage and entangle rules and the stumble/fumble rules.
With a total of 16+ injury points, a human passes out and is incapacitated. This value can be randomized evyr time a wound is taken and is modified by Stamina through Row-5-addition.
These pages are taken as is.
These pages are ignored or taken as descriptive material.

Any wound needs to heal its injury points. This is calculated via Stamina; certain medicine may improve the healing rate. A physician may make a skill roll to find or create the correct medicine but his skill is not added to the healing resolution directly.

A serious wound may become infected (until it turns into a minor wound). An infection is a daily attack on the wounded area with a level of the wound, defended against with Stamina. Medicine applies in the same way as for minor wounds, but it harder to obtain. A penalty of 5 is suitable. Any injury points gained through the infection is added to the original wound. This may turn the wound into a grievous wound.

A grevious wound is a bleeder or otherwise makes the body lose vital fluids. Bloodloss is treated as a separate injury, and increases at -10 per 10s. E.g., a 12 point injury causes 1 point of bloodloss to accrue every 5 seconds. Note that the circulatory system is incapacitated with 16 points as other body parts are. The circulatory system itself will not turn infectious. Treatment by physicians depend on the location. Some locations are incurable by Harnic physicians. For multiple bleeders only take the maximum in the same extremity, but add those for different extremities.

Incapacitating and destroying wounds have no additional effects over the bleeder and infection dangers. (A 22 destroying wound causes more than 1 point per second in bloodloss and only very unlikely circumstances will keep the victim alive for more than 15 seconds.)
Amputations and immediate cauterizations stop infections.
